Comparative Analysis on the Shift from Rule-Based Expert Systems to Modern AI Approaches:

In the 1970s, expert systems emerged as a branch of Artificial Intelligence (AI), marking the beginning of the shift from rule-based expert systems ([1], [2]). These systems were designed to emulate human expertise by incorporating specialized knowledge elicited from domain experts ([1]). Expert systems found their popularity and application in various fields, such as engineering, chemistry, medicine, industry, and others, during the early 1980s when they moved out of research laboratories ([1]). The construction process of these expert systems, referred to as knowledge engineering, involved acquiring knowledge from periodicals, books, or interviews with human experts ([1]). The general architecture of an expert system consisted of a user interface, explanation facility, working memory, and inference engine ([1]). However, research on the representation and management of uncertainty in rule-based reasoning was primarily focused in the field of AI during this period ([2]). By the mid-1980s to late 1990s, there is no explicit evidence in the provided context that signifies a significant shift from rule-based expert systems to modern AI approaches. The focus seems to be on refining and improving the efficiency of these systems rather than transitioning to new paradigms ([1]). References:
[1] Expert_Systems.pdf (2016)
[2] 1304.1083v1.pdf (1989)
